G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 186, § 14, every landlord is prohibited from “directly or indirectly” interfering with the quiet enjoyment of a residential tenant, and may be held liable for actual and statutory damages where such interference occurs.

G.L. c. 186.proposition: Plaintiff’s tenancy is and at all relevant times has been a residential tenancy subject to G.L. c. 186 and G.L. c. 239, and to the implied warranty of habitability under Massachusetts law.

G.L. c. 239.proposition: Plaintiff’s tenancy is and at all relevant times has been a residential tenancy subject to G.L. c. 186 and G.L. c. 239, and to the implied warranty of habitability under Massachusetts law.

105 CMR 410.000 et seq..proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant had care, custody, control, and responsibility for maintenance of the building and common structural systems, and for providing an apartment fit for human habitation, including freedom from rodent infestation, as required by the State Sanitary Code, 105 CMR 410.000 et seq., and G.L. c. 111, § 127A.

G.L. c. 111, \u00a7 127A.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant had care, custody, control, and responsibility for maintenance of the building and common structural systems, and for providing an apartment fit for human habitation, including freedom from rodent infestation, as required by the State Sanitary Code, 105 CMR 410.000 et seq., and G.L. c. 111, § 127A.

105 CMR 410.550.proposition: The Massachusetts State Sanitary Code expressly requires that every dwelling be kept “free from infestation of rodents, skunks, cockroaches, and insect pests,” 105 CMR 410.550, and imposes on owners a duty to “exterminate and prevent infestation” where it exists in a dwelling containing more than one unit.

105 CMR 410.550\u2013410.560.proposition: The Massachusetts State Sanitary Code expressly requires that every dwelling be kept “free from infestation of rodents, skunks, cockroaches, and insect pests,” 105 CMR 410.550, and imposes on owners a duty to “exterminate and prevent infestation” where it exists in a dwelling containing more than one unit. See 105 CMR 410.550–410.560.

G.L. c. 218, \u00a7\u00a7 19\u201321.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§ 19–21 and G.L. c. 185C, § 3, because this is a civil action arising out of a residential landlord‑tenant relationship located in Worcester, Massachusetts, involving claims under G.L. c. 186.

G.L. c. 185C, \u00a7 3.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§ 19–21 and G.L. c. 185C, § 3, because this is a civil action arising out of a residential landlord‑tenant relationship located in Worcester, Massachusetts, involving claims under G.L. c. 186.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 2.proposition: Venue is proper in the Worcester District Court, Housing Court Department, pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 2 and G.L. c. 185C, § 3, because the real property that is the subject of this action is located in Worcester, Massachusetts, within this Court’s territorial jurisdiction.

Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.raw_text: Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973)
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.proposition: Plaintiff’s tenancy is and at all relevant times has been a residential tenancy subject to G.L. c. 186 and G.L. c. 239, and to the implied warranty of habitability under Massachusetts law. See Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973).
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.support_reasoning: The quoted portion is a concurrence/dissent, not the majority, but it accepts that these are residential tenancies governed procedurally by G.L. c. 239 summary process and substantively by the State Sanitary Code and related landlord‑tenant statutes. The majority opinion in Hemingway (not quoted here) is the seminal Massachusetts case recognizing an implied warranty of habitability in residential tenancies. Thus, as a whole, Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway does stand for the proposition that a residential tenancy is subject to G.L. c. 186, c. 239, and an implied warranty of habitability, though the specific excerpt focuses more on the scope and basis of that warranty than on the bare proposition that it exists for residential tenancies.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.relevant_excerpt: "I agree with the majority of the court that, at least as to dwelling units, the time has come to reconsider the rule so long imbedded in our law of landlord and tenant that ‘[t]here is no implied agreement, apart from fraud, that the demised premises are or will continue to be fit for occupancy or safe and in good repair ...’ ... As the first step in the removal of the roadblock discussed above I would reverse that rule and hold ... that by renting such a unit the landlord impliedly agrees with his tenant ... that the rented unit complies with those standards..."

McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304 (.raw_text: McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304 (1977)
McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304 (.proposition: Upon discovering the mouse droppings, Plaintiff promptly notified Defendant of the rodent problem verbally and/or in writing, fulfilling her duty to notify the landlord of conditions requiring repair. See McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304 (1977).
McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304 (.support_reasoning: The opinion does not discuss any facts about a tenant discovering rodent droppings, notifying the landlord, or the manner or timeliness of tenant notice. It only mentions, in general, that damages run from when the landlord knew or was notified of defects, without elaborating on what constitutes proper or sufficient tenant notice. Therefore it does not provide authority for the specific proposition that the plaintiff promptly notified the defendant of a rodent problem, verbally or in writing, in satisfaction of a duty to notify conditions requiring repair.
McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304 (.relevant_excerpt: "We also ruled that damages were to be computed from the inception of the tenancy if it were shown that the defective conditions existed at that time. But, if the defects arose during the tenancy, damages were to be computed from the time when the landlord first knew or was notified of their existence. Id. at 174."

Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.raw_text: Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907 (1987)
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.proposition: Rodent infestations, including the presence of droppings in food preparation and storage areas, are conditions that materially impair the health, safety, and well‑being of occupants and constitute a violation of the State Sanitary Code. See 105 CMR 410.550; see also Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907 (1987).
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.support_reasoning: The opinion lists “mice” as one of several State Sanitary Code violations in the tenant’s apartment, but it does not discuss rodent infestations, droppings in food areas, or 105 CMR 410.550 in its reasoning or holdings. The case is focused on heat and hot water obligations, security deposits, rent control overcharges, habitability damages generally, and c. 93A applicability. It therefore does not expressly establish that rodent infestations in food preparation or storage areas are conditions that materially impair health and constitute a sanitary code violation; at most, it implicitly treats the presence of mice as a code violation without elaboration.
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.relevant_excerpt: “Several violations of the State Sanitary Code, 105 Code Mass. Regs. § 410.000 (1983), have existed in the tenant’s apartment since Young and his mother acquired the property. … The violations include the existence of lead paint, cracked windows, missing window screens, stained ceiling, loose bathroom tiles, mice, ants, missing balustrades on the porches, inadequate trash receptables, and inadequate door locks.”

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: Defendant’s failure to act adequately constitutes a breach of his statutory and common‑law obligations as landlord, including his duty not to interfere with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment of her tenancy, as provided by G.L. c. 186, § 14, and interpreted in cases such as Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994), and Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977).
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely holds that a landlord’s failure to act adequately in the face of serious, known interference (here, pervasive drug activity in common areas) can constitute a breach of the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14. The Court explains that a breach may arise from what the landlord “failed to do” and that if the landlord has taken no or inadequate measures to remove unwelcome persons whose presence seriously interferes with tenants’ use, the covenant is violated. That aligns with the proposition that inadequate action breaches statutory/common‑law landlord obligations not to interfere with quiet enjoyment, in the same line of authority as Blackett v. Olanoff.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “In analyzing whether there is a breach of the covenant, we examine the landlord’s conduct and not his intentions. Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716 (1977). Thus, a landlord may not intend to violate a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment, but may do so nevertheless when the breach is a ‘natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.’ … If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.proposition: Defendant’s failure to act adequately constitutes a breach of his statutory and common‑law obligations as landlord, including his duty not to interfere with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment of her tenancy, as provided by G.L. c. 186, § 14, and interpreted in cases such as Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994), and Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977).
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.support_reasoning: Blackett holds that a landlord breaches the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment when conditions that substantially deprive tenants of quiet enjoyment are the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, failed to do, or permitted, and that the landlord’s conduct, not intent, is controlling. It further rejects a nonfeasance/malfeasance distinction where the landlord created the situation and had the right to control the objectionable condition. This directly supports using landlord inaction or inadequate action as a breach of common‑law and statutory quiet‑enjoyment obligations, as later reflected in cases like Doe.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.relevant_excerpt: “There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done…. [T]he landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling…. To the extent that our opinions suggest a distinction between nonfeasance by the landlord… and malfeasance by the landlord, we decline to perpetuate that distinction where the landlord creates a situation and has the right to control the objectionable conditions.”

Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782.raw_text: Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782 (1994)
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782.proposition: Plaintiff reserves the right to prove at trial additional consequential damages, including but not limited to diminution in the fair rental value of the Premises during the period of infestation and emotional distress associated with the unsanitary and unsafe conditions. See Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782 (1994); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758 (1979).
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns the types of consequential damages a plaintiff may prove at trial (including diminution in rental value during infestation and emotional distress). Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas deals with rent abatement damages for breach of the implied warranty of habitability and statutory violations, but it does not discuss or authorize additional consequential damages such as emotional distress or separate diminution in rental value beyond the contract-rent-based abatement. The opinion’s focus is on how to calculate habitability damages in subsidized housing and entitlement to attorney’s fees, not on expanding categories of consequential damages at trial.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782.relevant_excerpt: “Thomas was entitled to damages calculated on the basis of value of the premises as warranted. Wideman, supra at 775-777. As the parties have not argued otherwise, we assume that the contract rent, which by Federal law must approximate the fair market value of the leased premises, see 24 C.F.R. §§ 881.203 and 881.204 (1993), is equal to the value of the premises as warranted. On remand, therefore, the contract rent should be used as the basis for calculating a new award of damages.”

Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.raw_text: Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758 (1979)
Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.proposition: Plaintiff reserves the right to prove at trial additional consequential damages, including but not limited to diminution in the fair rental value of the Premises during the period of infestation and emotional distress associated with the unsanitary and unsafe conditions. See Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782 (1994); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758 (1979).
Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.support_reasoning: The proposition claims authority for recovering additional consequential damages including diminution in rental value and emotional distress. Darmetko does recognize that actual damages include diminution in value of the leasehold and consequential damages to personal property under G.L. c. 186, § 14, but it expressly notes that the tenant’s emotional-distress claim was not proved and does not hold that emotional distress is a recoverable element of damages here. Thus, it supports diminution-in-value and consequential property damages, but not the broader statement including emotional distress as asserted in the proposition.
Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “It is clear that the plaintiff’s actual damages exceeded three times her monthly rent of $47. Her actual damages included the diminution of the value of the leasehold due to the breach of the implied warranty of habitability, as well as the damage to her personal property. Damages for the breach were $793.50, and damage to her personal property was $415… The judge found that a claim of emotional distress due to the BHA’s failure to repair the premises had not been proved.”

Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.raw_text: Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196 (1979)
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.proposition: Substantial violations of the State Sanitary Code that persist after the landlord has notice have been held to constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14. See Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196 (1979); Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907 (1987).
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns breach of the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14; this opinion deals exclusively with breach of the implied warranty of habitability and rent abatement, not with § 14 or quiet enjoyment. Although the court refers to substantial State Sanitary Code violations (loss of heat and hot water) as making the premises uninhabitable and justifying rent abatement, it does not analyze or hold that such conditions constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. Thus, using Berman as authority for the specific § 14 quiet-enjoyment proposition is inaccurate.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “A dwelling afflicted with a substantial Sanitary Code violation is not habitable. The essential objective of the warranty is to make sure that the tenant receives what she is paying for. The tenant may not excuse her obligation with mere reasonable efforts to pay rent. Nor may the landlord avoid his duty with mere reasonable efforts to provide a habitable dwelling. The contract between the parties, seen through the law’s clarifying lens, requires such symmetry.”

Al\u2011Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is an express statutory right and an implied term of every residential lease in Massachusetts. See Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994); Al‑Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).
Al\u2011Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely interprets and applies the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, but it does not state that quiet enjoyment is an implied term of every residential lease, nor does it describe it as an "express statutory right" in those terms. The court notes that § 14 codified common-law rights under the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, but it does not itself formulate the broader proposition that every residential lease in Massachusetts contains this implied covenant. Thus, while contextually consistent with the proposition, the case is not direct authority for that specific statement.
Al\u2011Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 186, § 14, originally enacted in 1927, codified a tenant’s common law rights under the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment. St. 1927, c. 339, § 1. See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 101-102 (1982). At common law, and as originally enacted by statute, the covenant of quiet enjoyment prohibited a landlord from wilful or intentional interference with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the leased premises.”

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, Defendant is liable to Plaintiff for (a) actual damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, and reasonable attorneys’ fees and costs. Although Plaintiff is self‑represented and not presently claiming attorneys’ fees, she is entitled at minimum to her actual damages and any enhanced statutory damages the Court deems appropriate. See Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758 (1979); Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: Simon squarely interprets G.L. c. 186, § 14, holding that a landlord who interferes with quiet enjoyment is liable for “actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, and the costs of the action, including a reasonable attorney’s fee,” and discusses Darmetko for the same point. The opinion also explains that the triple‑rent remedy is an alternative minimum recovery when actual damages are low, and confirms that attorney’s fees are awarded under § 14, which aligns with the proposition about the measure of damages and fees (even though Simon involved a represented tenant).
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “A landlord that violates § 14 is subject to a fine or imprisonment, and is liable to its tenants for ‘actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater,’ plus costs and attorneys’ fees. See Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758 (1979). … We believe, for reasons stated below, that all the items of damage that the jury might have included in its verdicts — including emotional injury — are recoverable under § 14.”
